Because you'd want to use the right &bci; for the project at hand.

Understand the differences and pick the right &bci; images for your projects.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: &suse; offers several general-purpose &bci;s that are intended as deployment targets or as foundations for creating customized images: bci-base, bci-minimal, bci-micro, and bci-busybox. These images share the common &slsa; base, and none of them ship with a specific language or an application stack. All images features the RPM database (even if the specific image does not include the RPM package manager) that can be used to verify the provenance of every file in the image. Each image includes the &slsa; certificate bundle, which allows the deployed applications to use the system's certificates to verify TLS connections.

section.title: BCI-base: When you need flexibilitity
section.para: This &bci; comes with the &zypper; package manager and includes the free SLE-BCI repository. This allows you to install software available in the reposity and customize the image during the build. The downside is the size of the image. It is the largest of the general-purpose &bci;s, so it's not always the best choice for a deployment image.

section.title: BCI-minimal: When you don't need &zypper;
section.para: This image is a stripped down version of bci-base. bci-minimal comes without &zypper;, but it does have the RPM package manager installed. This significantly reduces the size of the image. However, while rpm can install and remove packages, it lacks support for repositories and automated dependency resolution. The bci-minimal is therefore intended for creating deployment containers, and then installing the desired RPM packages inside the containers. Although you can install the required dependencies, you have to download and resolve them manually. However this approach is not recommended as it is prone to errors.

section.title: BCI-micro: When you need to deploy static binaries
section.para: This image is similar to bci-minimal but without the rpm package manager. The primary use case for this image is deploying static binaries produced externally or during multi-stage builds. As there is no straightforward way to install additional dependencies inside the container image, we recommend deploying a project using the bci-minimal image only when the final build artifact bundles all dependencies and has no external runtime requirements (like Python or Ruby).

section.title: BCI-busyBox: When you need the smallest and GPLv3-free image
section.para: Similar to bci-micro, the bci-busybox comes with the most basic tools only. However, in bci-busybox, these tools are provided by the BusyBox project. This has the benefit of further size reduction. Futhermore, the image contains no GPLv3 licensed software. When using the image, keep in mind that there are certain differences between the BusyBox tools and the GNU Coreutils. So scripts written for a system that uses GNU Coreutils may require modification to work with BusyBox.
